conclusion: Analyze the motion of positively charged particles through the velocity selector and determine the kinetic energy of the second particle when it leaves the selector.
The velocity selector consists of perpendicular electric and magnetic fields.
The electric field exerts a force F_E = qE and the magnetic field exerts a force F_B = qvB on a charged particle.
For a particle to pass through the selector undeflected, the forces must balance: qE = qvB, thus v = E/B.
The first particle has mass m and charge q, accelerated from rest by the accelerator M.
The first particle enters the velocity selector with velocity v = E/B and passes through undeflected, indicating its velocity is the selected velocity.
The second particle has mass 2m and charge q, also accelerated from rest by the accelerator M.
Both particles gain the same kinetic energy from the accelerator: (1/2)mv^2 = qU.
For the second particle: (1/2)(2m)v_2^2 = qU, leading to v_2 = sqrt(qU/m).
The second particle deviates from the dashed line because its velocity v_2 is different from the selector's selected velocity v = E/B.
The kinetic energy E_k of the second particle when it leaves the selector is E_k = (1/2)(2m)v_2^2 = qU.
The kinetic energy E_k of the second particle when it leaves the velocity selector is qU.
